content.description: a math trick (2017 Spring, Midterm 2, Question 3)

p.line: Assume that we have two blocks: _CODES_reverse_CODEE_, which reverses the numbers (leading zeros go away), and _CODES_plus2_CODEE_, who adds 2 to the number.

Imagine a single, compound expression made up of both of these blocks intermingled and composed together (none, some, or possibly very many of each), like the example above: "reverse(reverse(plus2(reverse())))". If the output of this (possibly large) expression were 7, which could have been the input?
Any integer could be the input, because 7 is a special number
The compound expression could convert any integer to any positive integer

content.hint: They are all possible. The secret to this question is that you can drop a zero by reversing a multiple of 10 (as in the example, 1230 becomes 321). That’s easy for even numbers, since you can just get to a multiple of 10, then reverse it twice to drop the 0. For odd numbers it seems impossible, but all you need to do is add 2 until your most significant digit is even, then reverse it, and you’re all set (just add 2 until you get to 700 or 7000 etc and reverse it).
